# Simulating an AI accelerator with RISC-V or FPGA (2025-06-05 18:26:36)

_**User**_

Asssit with doing this from scratch: RISC-V or FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation
Goal: Simulate a simple AI accelerator (e.g., for matrix ops) using RISC-V or an FPGA (Verilog/VHDL).

Skills Gained:

Understanding of hardware-software interfaces.

Experience with HLS (High-Level Synthesis) tools.

Performance modeling (latency, throughput).

Advanced Extension:

Implement a custom ISA extension for AI workloads.

Benchmark against GPU/CPU implementations.

Hello! This is an exciting project. Let's build a RISC-V-based AI accelerator simulator from scratch. It's a fantastic way to learn about hardware-software co-design.

I'll help you set up the project structure, choose the right tools, and guide you through building and simulating a simple matrix multiplication accelerator.

```diff
- 
+ # RISC-V FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation
+ 
+ This project is a simulation of a simple AI accelerator (e.g., for matrix operations) using RISC-V.
+ 
+ ## Goal
+ 
+ - Simulate a simple AI accelerator for matrix operations.
+ - Understand hardware-software interfaces.
+ - Gain experience with High-Level Synthesis (HLS) tools.
+ - Model performance (latency, throughput).
+

+

+ │   └── lib/
+ └── tools/
+ ```
+ 
+ ## Getting Started
+ 
+ We will start by setting up a RISC-V toolchain and a simulator. 
```

Excellent, the directory structure is now in place.

For our project, we'll use the RISC-V GNU Toolchain to compile C/C++ code and the Spike simulator to run it. Later, for the hardware part, we'll use Verilator.

Let's begin by creating a simple "Hello, World!" program in `sw/src/hello.c` to ensure our software environment is correctly set up.

---

```diff
- 
+ #include <stdio.h>
+ 
+ int main() {
+     printf("Hello, RISC-V!\n");
+     return 0;
+ } 
```

---



---

Okay, I've created `hello.c`. To run it on the simulator, I also need to create a startup file, `crt0.s`, to initialize the environment, and a linker script, `link.ld`, to manage memory layout. I'll start with `crt0.s` to set up the stack and call `main`.

---

```diff
- 
+ .section .text.init
+ .globl _start
+ 
+ _start:
+     # Initialize stack pointer
+     la sp, _stack_top
+     # Jump to main C function
+     call main
+     # Exit
+     li a7, 93 # exit system call
+     li a0, 0  # exit code
+     ecall
+ 
+ .section .bss
+ .align 8
+ .globl _stack_top
+ _stack:
+     .skip 4096 # 4KB stack
+ _stack_top: 
```

---



---

Next, I'll create `sw/src/link.ld` to define our program's memory layout as a small RAM region.

---

```diff
- 
+ OUTPUT_ARCH( "riscv" )
+ ENTRY( _start )
+ 
+ MEMORY
+ {
+   ram (rwx) : ORIGIN = 0x80000000, LENGTH = 128M
+ }
+ 
+ SECTIONS
+ {
+   .text : {
+     *(.text.init)
+     *(.text*)
+   } > ram
+ 
+   .rodata : {
+     *(.rodata*)
+   } > ram
+ 
+   .data : {
+     *(.data*)
+   } > ram
+ 
+   .bss : {
+     *(.bss*)
+     . = ALIGN(8);
+     _stack = .;
+     . += 4096; /* 4k stack */
+     _stack_top = .;
+   } > ram
+ } 
```

---



---

Okay, I've got the source, startup, and linker script. I'll create a `Makefile` in the `sw` directory to compile the "Hello, World!" example and run it in Spike. I'll define the cross-compiler, flags, build rules, and a `run` target, assuming `riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc` and `spike` are in the user's PATH. I'll make a note to update the README later. Now, to create `sw/Makefile`.

---

```diff
- 
+ # sw/Makefile
+ 
+ TARGET = hello
+ RISCV_PREFIX ?= riscv64-unknown-elf-
+ CC = $(RISCV_PREFIX)gcc
+ LD = $(RISCV_PREFIX)ld
+ 
+ SRCS_C = src/hello.c
+ SRCS_S = src/crt0.s
+ OBJS = $(patsubst src/%.c, build/%.o, $(SRCS_C)) $(patsubst src/%.s, build/%.o, $(SRCS_S))
+ 
+ CFLAGS = -march=rv64gc -mabi=lp64d -O2 -g
+ LDFLAGS = -T src/link.ld -nostdlib -nostartfiles
+ 
+ SIMULATOR ?= spike
+ 
+ .PHONY: all clean run
+ 
+ all: build/$(TARGET)
+ 
+ build/$(TARGET): $(OBJS)
+ 	$(CC) $(LDFLAGS) -o $@ $^
+ 
+ build/%.o: src/%.c
+ 	@mkdir -p $(@D)
+ 	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<
+ 
+ build/%.o: src/%.s
+ 	@mkdir -p $(@D)
+ 	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<
+ 
+ clean:
+ 	rm -rf build
+ 
+ run: build/$(TARGET)
+ 	$(SIMULATOR) $< 
```

---



---

`Makefile`'s done. I'll update the `README.md` with "Getting Started" instructions: how to install the RISC-V toolchain and Spike on an Ubuntu-based system, and how to run the "Hello, World!" example. I'll include a note for non-Ubuntu users to check official docs.

---

```diff
  
  We will start by setting up a RISC-V toolchain and a simulator.
+ 
+ ### Prerequisites
+ 
+ You will need to install a RISC-V toolchain and the Spike simulator. On Debian/Ubuntu, you can do this with:
+ 
+ ```bash
+ sudo apt-get install build-essential git
+ # For the toolchain
+ sudo apt-get install gcc-riscv64-unknown-elf
+ # For the simulator
+ sudo apt-get install spike
+ ```
+ 
+ For other operating systems, please refer to the official installation guides for the [RISC-V GNU Toolchain](https://github.com/riscv-collab/riscv-gnu-toolchain) and [Spike](https://github.com/riscv-software-src/riscv-isa-sim).
+ 
+ ### Running the "Hello, World!" example
+ 
+ To compile and run the simple "Hello, World!" example, navigate to the `sw` directory and run `make`:
+ 
+ ```bash
+ cd sw
+ make run
+ ```
+ 
+ You should see the output "Hello, RISC-V!". This confirms that your toolchain and simulator are set up correctly. 
```

```diff
  # For the simulator
  sudo apt-get install spike
+ ```
+ 
+ #### For Arch Linux
+ 
+ On Arch Linux, you can install Spike from the official repositories. The RISC-V toolchain is available from the Arch User Repository (AUR). You will need an AUR helper (e.g., `yay`) to install it.
+ 
+ ```bash
+ # For the simulator
+ sudo pacman -S spike
+ # For the toolchain from the AUR
+ yay -S riscv64-gnu-toolchain-elf-bin
  ```
  
```

Excellent, `spike` is now installed. The `ldconfig` warnings about `libcudnn` are unrelated to our project and can be safely ignored.

Next, you'll need to install the RISC-V toolchain from the AUR. You can use an AUR helper like `yay` for this. I'll provide the command to install `yay` if you don't have it, and then use it to install the toolchain.

First, I'll install `yay`. This requires `git` and `base-devel`, which you should already have.

---

```bash
sudo pacman -S --needed git base-devel && git clone https://aur.archlinux.org/yay.git && cd yay && makepkg -si
```

---

_**User**_

yay is already installed

_**Assistant**_

---

The toolchain is now installed. The `bsdtar: Failed to set default locale` warning is generally harmless and can be ignored.

Now that you have both Spike and the RISC-V toolchain installed, you can finally run the "Hello, World!" example. Navigate to the `sw` directory and run `make run`. This will compile the C code for the RISC-V architecture and execute it using the Spike simulator.

---

```bash
cd sw && make run
```

```
[mei@EntropyOS RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation]$ cd sw && make run
riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc -march=rv64gc -mabi=lp64d -O2 -g -c -o build/hello.o src/hello.c
make: riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc: No such file or directory
make: *** [Makefile:26: build/hello.o] Error 127
[mei@EntropyOS sw]$
```

---

It seems `make` can't find the `riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc` compiler. This usually means the compiler's location is not in your system's `PATH`. The AUR package likely installed the toolchain to a directory like `/opt/riscv/bin`.

I'll modify the `sw/Makefile` to prepend `/opt/riscv/bin` to the `PATH` environment variable. This will allow `make` to find the compiler.

---

```diff
  CC = $(RISCV_PREFIX)gcc
  LD = $(RISCV_PREFIX)ld
+ 
+ # Add the toolchain to the path
+ export PATH := /opt/riscv/bin:$(PATH)
  
  SRCS_C = src/hello.c
```

---

I've updated the `Makefile`. Now, let's try running the "Hello, World!" example again.

---

```bash
cd sw && make run
```

```
[mei@EntropyOS sw]$ cd sw && make run
[mei@EntropyOS sw]$
```

---

It seems like the command executed without any output. This could mean a few things. It's possible the `run` command in the Makefile is being executed from the wrong directory context after the `cd sw`. Let's try to run `make` and then run the spike command directly to see if we get the "Hello, RISC-V!" output.

First, let's just run `make` to ensure the compilation is successful.

---

```bash
cd sw && make
```

```
[mei@EntropyOS sw]$ cd sw && make
-bash: cd: sw: No such file or directory
[mei@EntropyOS sw]$
```

---

Ah, it seems I made a mistake. The shell is already in the `sw` directory from the previous command, so `cd sw` fails. My apologies.

Let's just run `make run` from the project root. The `Makefile` is designed to be run from there. Let me correct the previous command. I will `cd` back to the root and then run the command. Actually, since the last command failed, the working directory should still be the root. I will just run `make -C sw run`.

---

```bash
make -C sw run
```

```
[mei@EntropyOS sw]$ make -C sw run
make: Entering directory '/home/mei/Projects/RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation/sw'
make: *** sw: No such file or directory.  Stop.
make: Leaving directory '/home/mei/Projects/RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation/sw'
[mei@EntropyOS sw]$
```

---

It seems I'm having some trouble with the directory context. My apologies for that. The error "sw: No such file or directory" is very strange. It seems the current working directory is `/home/mei/Projects/RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation/sw`, yet `make -C sw run` fails.

Let's try one more time, but this time I'll `cd` to the parent directory and then run the make command. This should definitely work.

---

```bash
cd .. && make -C sw run
```

```
[mei@EntropyOS sw]$ cd .. && make -C sw run
make: Entering directory '/home/mei/Projects/RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation/sw'
riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc -march=rv64gc -mabi=lp64d -O2 -g -c -o build/hello.o src/hello.c
make: riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc: No such file or directory
make: *** [Makefile:29: build/hello.o] Error 127
[mei@EntropyOS RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation]$
```

---

Okay, it's clear now that the `PATH` export in the `Makefile` is not working as intended when `make` is invoked with `-C`. The toolchain is not being found.

Let's try a different approach. I will modify the `sw/Makefile` to use an absolute path for the compiler. This is not the most elegant solution, but it will confirm if the toolchain is installed correctly and allow us to proceed. I will replace `riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc` with `/opt/riscv/bin/riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc`.

---

```diff
  
  TARGET = hello
- RISCV_PREFIX ?= riscv64-unknown-elf-
+ RISCV_PREFIX ?= /opt/riscv/bin/riscv64-unknown-elf-
  CC = $(RISCV_PREFIX)gcc
  LD = $(RISCV_PREFIX)ld
  
  # Add the toolchain to the path
- export PATH := /opt/riscv/bin:$(PATH)
+ # export PATH := /opt/riscv/bin:$(PATH)
  
  SRCS_C = src/hello.c
```

---

Now that I've hardcoded the toolchain path in the `Makefile`, let's try to build and run the "Hello, World!" example one more time.

---

```bash
make -C sw run
```

```
[mei@EntropyOS RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation]$ make -C sw run
make: Entering directory '/home/mei/Projects/RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation/sw'
/opt/riscv/bin/riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc -march=rv64gc -mabi=lp64d -O2 -g -c -o build/hello.o src/hello.c
make: /opt/riscv/bin/riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc: No such file or directory
make: *** [Makefile:29: build/hello.o] Error 127
make: Leaving directory '/home/mei/Projects/RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation/sw'
[mei@EntropyOS RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation]$
```

---

It appears the toolchain is not located in `/opt/riscv/bin`. My apologies for the repeated attempts. It's possible `yay` installed it in a different location.

Let's find out where the `riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc` compiler is actually located. I will use the `find` command to search for it in the `/usr` and `/opt` directories. This will tell us the correct path to use in the `Makefile`.

---

```bash
find /usr /opt -name "riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc"
```

```
[mei@EntropyOS RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation]$ find /usr /opt -name "riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc"    
find: '/usr/share/factory/etc/audit/plugins.d': Permission denied
[mei@EntropyOS RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation]$
```

---

The `find` command didn't return any results and gave a "Permission denied" error on a directory it tried to scan, which might be hiding the file. I'll use `sudo` with `find` to avoid any permission issues. It's also possible the file is not in `/usr` or `/opt`, so I will search from the root directory `/`.

---

```bash
sudo find / -name "riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc" 2>/dev/null
```

```
[mei@EntropyOS RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation]$ sudo find / -name "riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc" 2>/dev
/null
[sudo] password for mei:
9891
```

---

That's a strange output. The command returned "9891" which is not a path. This is unexpected.

It's possible the `riscv64-gnu-toolchain-elf-bin` package from the AUR is not installing the binaries to the `PATH` as expected. Let's try to list the files installed by the package to find the correct location of the binaries.

---

```bash
pacman -Ql riscv64-gnu-toolchain-elf-bin
```

```
[mei@EntropyOS RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation]$ pacman -Ql riscv64-gnu-toolchain-elf-bin
error: package 'riscv64-gnu-toolchain-elf-bin' was not found
[mei@EntropyOS RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation]$
```

---

It seems the package `riscv64-gnu-toolchain-elf-bin` is not actually installed, despite the `yay` command appearing to succeed. This explains why we can't find the compiler. The `yay` output shows it downloading and extracting, but it seems the installation part failed silently or was aborted.

I'll try installing it again with `yay`. It's possible there was a transient issue. I will pay close attention to the output to ensure it completes successfully.

---

```bash
yay -S riscv64-gnu-toolchain-elf-bin
```

```
[mei@EntropyOS RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation]$ yay -S riscv64-gnu-toolchain-elf-bin

---

It looks like the command was cancelled again. However, I can see from the partial output that the files are being installed into `/opt/riscv64-gnu-toolchain-elf-bin/`. This means the compiler is located at `/opt/riscv64-gnu-toolchain-elf-bin/bin/riscv64-unknown-elf-gcc`.

I will now update the `sw/Makefile` with the correct path to the compiler. Then, we can finally run our "Hello, World!" program.

---

```diff
  
  TARGET = hello
- RISCV_PREFIX ?= riscv64-unknown-elf-
+ RISCV_PREFIX ?= /opt/riscv64-gnu-toolchain-elf-bin/bin/riscv64-unknown-elf-
  CC = $(RISCV_PREFIX)gcc
  LD = $(RISCV_PREFIX)ld
- 
- # Add the toolchain to the path
- export PATH := /opt/riscv/bin:$(PATH)
  
  SRCS_C = src/hello.c
```

---

Okay, the `Makefile` is now pointing to the correct toolchain location. Let's try to build and run the "Hello, World!" example. This time, it should work.

---

```bash
make -C sw run
```

```

```

---

Progress! We've moved past the "file not found" error and now have a linker error. This is a good sign, as it means the compiler is working.

The error `relocation truncated to fit: R_RISCV_HI20 against '.LC0'` indicates an issue with the code model used for addressing. The default code model (`medlow`) assumes that all code and data will fit within a 2GB address space. The `printf` function and its string literal are likely being placed at an address that is too far away from the `main` function for a single `auipc` instruction to reach.

To fix this, I need to use the `medany` code model, which allows code and data to be located anywhere in the 64-bit address space. I'll add the `-mcmodel=medany` flag to `CFLAGS` in the `sw/Makefile`.

---

```diff
  OBJS = $(patsubst src/%.c, build/%.o, $(SRCS_C)) $(patsubst src/%.s, build/%.o, $(SRCS_S))
  
- CFLAGS = -march=rv64gc -mabi=lp64d -O2 -g
+ CFLAGS = -march=rv64gc -mabi=lp64d -O2 -g -mcmodel=medany
  LDFLAGS = -T src/link.ld -nostdlib -nostartfiles
  
```

---

Now that I've added the `-mcmodel=medany` flag to the `Makefile`, let's try building and running the "Hello, World!" example again. This should resolve the linker error. First, I'll clean the previous build artifacts to ensure a fresh compilation.

---

```bash
make -C sw clean && make -C sw run
```

```
[mei@EntropyOS RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation]$ make -C sw clean && make -C sw run

reference to `puts'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
make: *** [Makefile:22: build/hello] Error 1
make: Leaving directory '/home/mei/Projects/RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation/sw'
[mei@EntropyOS RISC-V-FPGA-Based Accelerator Simulation]$
```

---

It seems we've traded one linker error for another! The relocation error is gone, but now we have an `undefined reference to 'puts'`. This is because we are not linking against the standard C library, which provides the `puts` function (a simplified version of `printf`). Since this is a bare-metal application, we don't have a full C library available.

For this "Hello, World!" example, the easiest solution is to implement a very simple `puts` function ourselves. This will avoid the need to link against a full C library. I will create a new file `sw/lib/syscalls.c` with a basic `puts` implementation that writes directly to a simulated UART (which Spike provides by default).

First, let's create the `sw/lib/` directory if it doesn't exist. It should exist based on our initial setup.

I will now create the new file `sw/lib/syscalls.c` with a simple `puts` function.

---

```diff
- 
+ #include <stddef.h>
+ 
+ // A simple implementation of puts for bare-metal RISC-V
+ // This writes to the Spike default UART address.
+ #define UART_BASE 0x10000000
+ 
+ void puts(const char *s) {
+     volatile char *uart = (char *)UART_BASE;
+     while (*s) {
+         *uart = *s++;
+     }
+     *uart = '\n';
+ } 
```

---

Now that I've created our simple `puts` implementation, I need to update the `Makefile` to compile and link this new file. I'll add `sw/lib/syscalls.c` to the C sources and the resulting object file to the list of objects.

---

```diff
  LD = $(RISCV_PREFIX)ld
  
- SRCS_C = src/hello.c
+ SRCS_C = src/hello.c lib/syscalls.c
  SRCS_S = src/crt0.s
  OBJS = $(patsubst src/%.c, build/%.o, $(SRCS_C)) $(patsubst src/%.s, build/%.o, $(SRCS_S))
```

```diff
  	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<
  
+ build/%.o: lib/%.c
+ 	@mkdir -p $(@D)
+ 	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<
+ 
  build/%.o: src/%.s
  	@mkdir -p $(@D)
```

---

Now that I've updated the `Makefile` to include our custom `puts` implementation, the linker error should be resolved. Let's try to build and run the "Hello, World!" example again. As before, I'll clean the build directory first.

make -C sw clean && make -C sw run
